title: Japanese Patrol Boat Collides With North Korean Fishing Vessel
text:
A Japan patrol boat at the site of its collision with a North Korean fishing boat, in a photo released by the Japan Coast Guard.

TOKYO—A North Korean boat that was fishing for squid in the Sea of Japan sank after colliding with a Japanese patrol boat, but North Korean crew members said all the people on the boat were rescued, Japanese officials said.

A Japan Coast Guard spokesman said another North Korean boat on the scene picked up fishermen who were floating on life rafts after the collision. The North Korean side told Japan by radio that about 60 people had been on the sunken boat and all were rescued, the spokesman said.

Japan earlier had estimated that about 20 North Korean fishermen were thrown into the sea after the collision. Tokyo said no one on the Japanese side was hurt.

Taku Eto, Japan’s minister of agriculture, forestry and fisheries, said an abrupt turn by the North Korean boat caused the collision. Photo: issei kato/Reuters While the incident ended apparently without loss of life, it points to rising tension over fishing rights in the Sea of Japan. The collision took place in Japan’s exclusive economic zone, where boats from other countries generally aren’t supposed to fish, and Tokyo has been stepping up patrols to enforce its rights. Monday’s incident started fairly routinely with a Japanese warning to the North Korean ship to leave the waters. But an abrupt turn by the North Korean boat caused a collision, according to Japanese officials. The accident occurred shortly after 9 a.m. Monday about 215 miles northwest of Japan’s Noto Peninsula, and the North Korean ship sank around 9:25 a.m. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has pressed his people to fill quotas for catching seafood, a source of foreign exchange for the isolated country. Dozens of North Korean vessels have washed up in Japan, sometimes with dead bodies aboard, suggesting that the push has forced fishermen to undertake missions for which their craft are ill-equipped.
